Kyle Goodman Brent, with only a topical comprehension of the situation, I can say that one, this appears to be an exceptional(as-in not common) event. Furthermore, I agree with you that the institutions which currently exist in our country will mismanage this event(as happens to be quite common, in my opinion).

I would pose that the institutions involved in policing, judgement, and therapy/correction need a re-structuring, as well as the public systems which allow the formation of, and often facilitate these forms of behavior.

Now the question is how should we approach this kind of reconstruction within the confines of our pseudo-democratic society? I feel it can be done, but like Daniel, I do not posess the capacity to do it alone.

I, personally, would propose the utilization of entertainment media like performances and multi-media presentations to encourage social adaptation, but this takes time, effort, and resources--and the results are not guatanteed.

However, well-done and well-presented art has been known to have a very large impact on the opinions and actions of individuals, and I choose this as my primary medium of advocating social change.

With the discussion of ontological developments in other threads this night, I am reminded of my short studies into Hakim Bey, and feel that we would benefit from modeling some of our presentations after his ideas and examples of radical art as a form of social intervention.

SpSonSsoSredS
 · September 13, 2017 ·

Meta-note on my last post [ https://www.facebook.com/ialdabaoth/posts/10211884149238032 ]:

I strongly feel that Public Relations, as it manifests in our community, is toxic cowardice. It is the cancer that is killing the LessWrong diaspora.

I recognize that this belief has VERY STRONG behavioral and risk implications, and if I'm wrong shit could be DIRE.

...

But I don't think I'm wrong, so the sane and responsible thing to do seems to be to double-crux with someone like Anna Salamon or Pete Michaud or Nate Soares or Rob Bensinger until everyone 'holding the reins' converges with me on an actual ontological vision.

If that can't happen, then the next sane and responsible thing to do is to shrug and keep doing risky things, and probably poach talented people until my side outnumbers the Official Side.

But I'm watching others engage in that strategy, and it fucking sucks. It creates schisms and splits in the community, gets everyone freaked the fuck out about each other, and actually creates a *more* toxic, paranoid and cowardly culture. So fuck that. We have *tools* for resolving ontological disputes; let's fucking use them.

See More
Brent Dill
September 13, 2017

Suppose I do something risky and socially out-of-bounds enough, that you'd expect it of 2012 Michael Vassar. I do this thing because I believe the payoff is wor...th the risk for the community, and I believe that no one else has the combination of insight to make the right call and skill to 'thread the needle'.

The problem is, I haven't earned the right to do such a thing, because I haven't 'put in my dues' by doing risky things that pay off for the community, yet.

The lack of permission makes it about 50% more difficult to 'thread the needle' than if I had permission, while I was only anticipating that it would be 25% more difficult. The extra difficulty actually shifts the odds enough that the payoff no longer seems worth the risk.

How do I avoid this error, without signalling capitulation in a way that increases the difficulty from lack of permission further?

Brent Dill Moving to less public spaces won't help the sorts of things I care about.

We need public spaces to draw crowds for recruiting, because people who are capable of Heroism are rare.

We need to perform extraordinary, risky, and bad-PR-producing actions when we find someone capable of Heroism, because our larger culture is toxic to Heroism and extraordinary measures are necessary to re-kindle these sparks before they're lost.

We need to be *comfortable* performing risky, extraordinary actions when people who understand Heroism notice a potential Hero, because any sign of fear actually makes the consensus culture *more* comfortable with attacking us for performing those actions.

Zero fucks need to be given, or we won't have anyone capable of saving the world in 20 years.

Rob Bensinger A few different thoughts come to mind:

1 - This is a thing I think has been under-discussed. I want to explicitly acknowledge that I'm thinking out loud to some extent, and that my beliefs/strategy are unusually liable to change as we poke at different sides of this.

I think it's valuable to flag tentativeness/flux feelings because otherwise the format of these kinds of conversations strongly encourages "everyone says their beliefs in really strong terms, to show that they're wise confident high-status intellectuals who have deeply considered all their thoughts and should be taken seriously".

2 - I think 'we need to be really public so that we can find the world's rare heroes and have them save us' is true-ish. I suspect it might be healthier to sort of disregard it over the next few years, though -- treat it as a footnote, don't include it in the mission statement -- and leave it to some specialists to handle reaching out to new people in a targeted and deliberate way, while building a space that's more strictly optimized for epistemics even if that makes it not-perfectly-accessible to the next newcomer who's an Eliezer. (Yes, even to the next Eliezer.)

I non-confidently suspect it would be healthier for us to spend most of our time assuming that we've already found at least 30% of the hero capacity we're ever going to, and that building capacity further is likely to be important but not completely game-changing. Even if this hypothesis is false, I think it might be epistemically healthy for us to do less buck-passing over the next ~2 years. It would remove some of the "oh god everything we do has to be about attracting amazing people to our community" PR perspective at the root (and I think having non-specialists focus on this issue has inevitable epistemic costs, if only because a lot of people will inevitably disagree with you about the best approach to attracting heroes), and encourage more nihil supernum mindset. And it would give people a chance to build up more robust habits/norms (including being better ourselves at "just be more courageous dammit" and "just be more calm+patient+vulnerable in working through disagreements dammit") and end up with an epistemically vibrant and inviting-in-the-right-way community.

Fragmentation might be good. Hostility is bad.

3 - I don't have confident views about the situation with you and Oliver. I haven't fully internalized Eliezer's mindset on civilizational inadequacy myself. I still suspect I'd find it valuable/interesting to have your points of disagreement with Oliver explicitly sketched out.

Rob Bensinger It does sound like there needs to be some sort of trade where, if we can't reach perfect universal epistemic convergence on the relevant questions, the people who think that on a psychological/spirtiual level we need to do something like maximizing bold open risk-taking (or who think the maxipok threshold for bold open risk-taking is, like, being as risk-taking as the top 1/10,000 humans) agree to some level of not-wrecking-the-plans of the people who think the maxipok threshold for bold open risk-taking is being like the top 1/1,000 humans (or whatever), and the latter group agree to some level of not-wrecking-the-plans of the former group. That kind of framework is needed in any case because the community is big and there will always be disagreements about what the right threshold is, and how to trade things off against each other.

Brienne Yudkowsky
September 11, 2017

podcast or talk show idea: "Double Crux"

(it would also be a fantastic variation on panels at conferences)

the host finds two cool people to talk to. they talk ...beforehand with each person separately, looking for a topic the two disagree about. (it may be important that they do it in that order. i don't expect it to work as well if you pick the topic first, then find a supporter and an opponent.)

on the podcast, the guests explore the topic with the host, while the host gently guides the guests through the double crux procedure. there's plenty of room for flexibility and spontaneity, but the objective is to move all three discussion members into better alignment with reality by drawing out and examining the cruxes.

with the right host, this is something i'd enjoy listening to regularly. it could also be quite valuable altruistically, mainly because it would serve as a model for truth-seeking discussion. plus, listeners would end up with a much deeper kind of understanding of the topics discussed than they'd get from explanations, ordinary conversation, or standard debate formats.

#rationalsphere

Brent Dill Yeah. I'll explain it here, because I'm tired of all the dumb.

Michael Vassar was one of the most potent thought-leaders in our community from like, 2010 to 2015.

Then something happened and the community started turning toxic to certain thoughts. Various decisions were made by MIRI and CFAR that changed the culture - mostly in necessary ways, but also in ways that make it far more risk-averse.

Risk-aversion brainkills people like Vassar and I.

Michael Arc (Vassar renamed after his second marriage) started building a coalition of people who he believes aren't brainkilled in that particular way. My opinion is that his selection criteria are faulty, because he's currently suffering a massive amount of social and emotional damage. My opinion is that CFAR's reaction has been equally unhealthy, because Anna Salamon is currently suffering an equally massive amount of social and emotional damage, due to close friendship with Michael Vassar.

This is causing LITERALLY FUCKING EVERYONE to pick sides in the most absurdly childish ways imaginable. And because they're using ontological and epistemic tools to fight their tribal wars, they're corrupting those very tools, WHICH IS WHAT OUR FUCKING TRIBE WAS SUPPOSED TO BE FOUNDED ON.

So I'm a bit concerned.

Kyle Goodman Instead of risk-aversion, look at the idea of risk management. Everything is a risk, but what and how much you want to risk is the real concern. For instance it cost us around 50-65k USD to assemble the Black Lotus camp, that was a very large risk to make, not only for the money bet on the project, but also the risk assumed when we put dancers in the sphere, which could add up to millions of dollars, if complete and utter failure were to occur(a collapse with 5-10 people being severely injured).

To manage that risk we followed a procedure which relied upon precise calculations to assemble and reinforce the structure of the sphere, and then I and a few others attempted to supervise the participants to avoid structural damage or personal injury--as well as the supervision and coordination that you and others gave during the assembly and deconstruction of said sphere. There are other risks, which include theft of our stored equipment which is being managed by locks, fences, security cameras and the like.

Complete risk-avoidance is impossible, but risk management is necessary.

Furthermore, on a level of individual consent, you must consider how much risk people with vested interests are willing to assume in any project.

Let's clarify what I am specifically getting at, by using the example of Tara's shoelessness during sphere deconstruction: I was concerned about her shoelessness for two reasons, one that she could injure herself, and two that her injury could cost us nit only time and money, but her capacity to serve as a "sphere monkey" in the future.

To extend this idea, say that you, Brent, were to act in such a way that would deprive our team of you, we would be hard pressed to find another functional coordinator to replace you, and it would cost us time, and even possibly our team's success. This would mean that the investments not made into physical capital could be lost.

So, if your point is to dissuade people from risk management, which can include avoidance(not aversion) of unnecessary or exceptional risk, then I question your capacity as a leader.

Duncan Sabien I buy that that's a thing people I know (including myself) can be susceptible to, but I also claim that people I know (including myself) are metacognitively savvy enough to at least hold sufficient epistemic uncertainty around said dynamic's presence to have structures in place just in case and to be able to ameliorate it when it crops up, i.e. we must still disagree somewhat about specific individuals and how much they're swayed by this, or it must be something that is more prevalent in subsets of the community I *don't* see.

More generally, I'm highly suspicious of any "you are bad/should feel guilt or shame/take costly steps to ameliorate" claim that is fundamentally non-falsifiable, as e.g. the implicit racial bias claim is in practice.

Davis Tower Kingsley Mostly I'm thinking of considerations like those described in this post:

http://effective-altruism.com/.../you_have_a_set_amount.../

In brief, I think having unusual ideas that even provoke a bit of backlash is actually very important to doing new and unusual things, but one has to be careful in order to prevent:

-Tearing down too many Chesterton's fences at once
-Coming off as a crank to potential collaborators
-Creating internal schisms or disalignments

I very much like Brent's comment with respect to expanding our line of weirdness credit by doing big, impressive things - those who have accomplished much are extended more credit along these lines, as we see with Elon Musk and the like.

That said, I do think we need to be careful about overplaying our hand. The rationalist community often (to me) seems to err on the wrong side of Chesterton's fences, and think that it would be prudent to rein in some of the more outlandish aspects of community jargon and the like, at least in public-facing contexts.

Daniel Satanove RE: chesterton's fences, you could go the other way on it. If you're running up against a chesterton's fence, that could mean that some other mechanism for a well ordered society has been broken, and that you should look for what is causing you to run into the chesterton's fence and fix *that*.

I also suspect that chesterton's fences frequently cannot be understood by virtue of being to complex for the human mind to reason about. There are problems that are too complex to solve, and there are problems whose solutions are too complex to check, for information theoretic reasons. Many of these chesterton's fences got here through evolution or some sort of cultural evolution like thing, which depends on slow enough mutation to work.

http://web.archive.org/.../szabo.best.vwh.net/tradition.html

Also, there's lots of weirdness that the rationalist community is doing that doesn't solve anything in particular and doesn't do anything towards the whole FAI problem, like polyamoury, and I don't see why the rationalist community should go and get more affordances to do weird stuff like that. The weird stuff should be FAI or philosophy or methodological stuff, not how to order society stuff.

Daniel Satanove I mean things like "should we overcome that taboo around being in a romantic relationship with more than one person at a time?" The taboo is the fence.

Yes, I'm referring to friendly artificial intelligence. You could say that the rationalist community is roughly oriented towards this goal. the rationalist community came about (roughly) because of Eliezer's sequences on lesswrong.com which are towards developing an adequate base of rationality to address that problem.

If you like programming metaphors, how do you change the behaviour of a 100,000 line spaghetti code function without breaking other 100,000 line spaghetti code functions in a 10,000,000 LoC codebase that was developed by some non-human optimization algorithm over 1000s of years? It will be impossible to do by just reading the code and doing simple debugging, and rewriting it is not an option at all. You'd probably want to look at that optimization algorithm, but changing the codebase by directing or influencing the optimization algorithm is going to take a loooong time.

Daniel Satanove Alexander: My best interpretation of you is that laws aren't these metaphysical barriers to action, and they are really just rules enforced by some governing body, and those laws only prevent you from doing things only insofar as that governing body goes and prevents you from taking action. Or a little more abstractly, societies have implicit rules and enforce them more subtly by giving and taking away status an the like, and you are only prevented from doing things only insofar as they actually block you from action.

This might not be the point you are making, but it seems like a reasonable sounding point so for efficiency's sake I will talk about it, and if I'm wrong you can come back in and say "that's not it" and appear so much more galaxy brained than me again.

Yes, laws "don't exist" in this particular sense of existing, but so what? Yes, you can go about doing what those laws say you cannot do (I'm more referring to the social laws here), but people believe in and enforce those laws for a reason, and that reason is hard/impossible to come across. Because it is hard/impossible to find out why that law is there, it is hard/impossible to reason about whether you should break it. It is hard/impossible to see what would happen if everyone starts breaking it. So, in general, you should avoid breaking it unless the situation is somewhat dire.

Kyle Goodman Look at laws from the point of Ontological Anarchy, before there were governments, people gathered based on strengths and common interests, and not to mention their genetic/oxytocin induced in-crowd(or better known as family/tribe). Before the word "Law" existed, there were common agreements on ways to behave, however primitive they may habe been. Government institutions evolved out of these systems of common agreement, in fact common agreement is how many governing systems came to be. It is to some degree true that Governments are large gangs that enforce these laws, but say that you remove the government from a society, what reaction are you going to get from stealing from, injuring, or killing another individual? Unless you are very sneaky, it's probably going to be bad. That having been said, there are "laws" so to speak that transcend the government due to common agreement. Now look at a government as a super-complex of intelligences that have banded together to better organize and optimize social functions. Now you're talking about what should be a primitive, highly erroneous, superintelligence, that in some ways should(doesn't always--but should) behave in a friendly fashion. Code is code, and code exists for a reason. The only diffenece between law and reactions is that one is managed and mediated by something attempting to optimize the process.

Duncan Sabien One thing that has not come up much within this thread so far is the difference between Public Relations vis-a-vis the community relating to the outside world, Public Relations vis-a-vis the community relating to itself internally, and Public Relations vis-a-vis the community figuring out where its boundaries lie and which swaths of territory are Israel, Palestine, West Bank, Gaza Strip, etc.

There's more than one mind-killing dance going on, and I suspect it's going to be difficult to make progress in any one of them without at least having respect for the causal influences of the other. There are things I can say to or about or in the presence of rationalists that I can't say with outsiders, things I can say to or about or in the presence of some rationalists that I can't say with other rationalists, and there are things I can say to or about or in the presence of rationalists that I can't say with social-culture-only rationalists, and all three of those are different, and all three are problems that could be meliorated.

Raymond Arnold Rationalist Town hall might be a good idea anyway for mostly unrelated reasons, but:

- I'm pro "not having weird layers of secrecy that distort things", but I think hashing out disagreements publicly *also* produces weird distortions. (i.e. people become worried about publicly losing face which turns them into politicians which is anti-epistemic)

- I do think some kind of deliberate resolution to the issues under discussion here would be good, and public discussion of that resolution *might* be good, but I'm fairly confident you'll get a saner output if the deliberate-resolution is private and the public discussion happens afterwards _after_ the people-who-disagree have reached agreement, or at least agreement on what they disagree on.

Not sure how well I understand Brent's goals with this thread but I think the main thing was "have a public enough thread to force the issue to get taken seriously by the people he wanted to take it seriously". (Which is frustrating for people who feel like they're *almost* able to understand/participate, but that's more of a necessary casualty than a "it was actually all that necessary for those people to participate in the first place.")

My model of Brent values things being out in the open, and also values having the conversation have the people who actually have the power/understanding to make the conversation useful, and I'm not sure if/how those things come into conflict here.

("what Brent prefers" isn't the only or best criterion here but seems relevant to understanding the current discussion)

Jacob Czynski As it is, most events can be arranged in blissful ignorance of the political dynamics unless the organizers or guests they value are closely involved. This means that politics can stay out of most interactions at most events; unless you're the organizer of a small event and invite me and also Alice Monday, you will continue not knowing that there's a conflict to avoid.
This situation is good, and is stable even if the proportion of true ignorance to pretense of ignorance drops until everyone actually knows. As long as not everyone knows that everyone knows, it's stable.

Write a reply...

Write a comment...
Brent Dill
SpSonSsoSredS
 · September 13, 2017 ·

Suppose I do something risky and socially out-of-bounds enough, that you'd expect it of 2012 Michael Vassar. I do this thing because I believe the payoff is worth the risk for the community, and I believe that no one else has the combination of insight to make the right call and skill to 'thread the needle'.

The problem is, I haven't earned the right to do such a thing, because I haven't 'put in my dues' by doing risky things that pay off for the community, yet.

The lack of ...permission makes it about 50% more difficult to 'thread the needle' than if I had permission, while I was only anticipating that it would be 25% more difficult. The extra difficulty actually shifts the odds enough that the payoff no longer seems worth the risk.

How do I avoid this error, without signalling capitulation in a way that increases the difficulty from lack of permission further?

See More

Brent Dill [This is an actual engineering question, not a social permission question. Attempts to approach or frame this as a social permission question will be greeted with a resounding 'fuck off'.]

Like
 · Reply · 1y · Edited
Noah Cohen Interesting. Well, communities naturally have PR-paranoid defenses against any individual's challenge to their status quos, and those defenses are commensurately especially aggressive against (perceived) selfish challenges, so it might be naive to imagine you can bypass a system that's organically defined by its intent to stop people from doing exactly what you're doing (Changing The Flow), but you might be able to lower the Barrier To Entry by making people think about why your proposed change is not, in fact, selfish. Though, this suggestion may be equally naive.

Oh! Also, I am interested in how this PR-paranoid system validates the 'payment of dues', because if that expense set is somehow married to permissions for this new action, there might be a way that you can implicitly TrojanHorse this new action into the act of paying the dues, and thereby pay-the-dues-and-do-the-new-action all at once, so that the new action can't be challeneged by the system without the system also challenging the very payment of dues which feeds it.

Context would help me be cleverer. Specific constraints are brain candy. :)

Daniel Powell There might be some biological reason why time alone is necessary. But where experience is the factor in question, providing lots of experience quickly is a goal worth pursuing. And I think that the things that happen when adults carefully craft experiences to be safe but provide experience negate the experience in ways that the adults don't notice.

Manage
Like
 · Reply · 1y
Kyle Goodman Sure, but will they be able to process high level experiences without sufficient neural ability in such a way that they will gain something valuable from those experiences? I know at-least one person who was exposed to a number of very high-level adult experiences in her youth, and albeit that in some ways she was more functional than others her age, she had also adopted a large number of unhealthy coping mechanisms along the way, including heavy tobacco, alcohol, cannabis, and unhealthy sexual habits. The alcohol starting as early as 12 or 13. At the same time, by age 18 she had already freed herself from her father's abusive grasp, and had begun a college education. It's definitely just a single story of a single person, and in no way represents a large sample, but I think that it is actually more valuable for parents(when they are able) to protect children from high-level experiences, so that they have the opportunity to develop slowly.
*For comparison, you wouldn't start weightlifting by trying to bench-press 500 pounds, you work up to it, over time as you learn proper technique and how to apply it to your body.
